results.title: Stella Stevens, Hollywood Bombshell Who Yearned for More, Dies at 84
results.abstract: She starred alongside the likes of Elvis Presley and Jerry Lewis. But she wanted to direct and write, and she felt held back by industry sexism.

results.title: Representation Among BAFTA Nominees Improves After Changes
results.abstract: Three years after an all-white lineup of actors was nominated, this year’s group is more diverse.

multimedia.caption: Ten of the 24 BAFTA performance nominations this year went to ethnically diverse people, including Ke Huy Quan for supporting actor in “Everything Everywhere All At Once,” and Angela Bassett for supporting actress in “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever.”
multimedia.copyright: Jennelle Fong for The New York Times; Rozette Rago for The New York Times

results.title: ‘The First Step’ Review: Van Jones Battles for Bipartisanship

results.title: ‘A Radiant Girl’ Review: Coming of Age in Paris, 1942

results.title: Raquel Welch, Actress and ’60s Sex Symbol, Is Dead at 82
results.abstract: Beginning with a doeskin bikini in “One Million Years B.C.,” she built a celebrated show business career around sex appeal and, sometimes, a comic touch.

multimedia.caption: When Playboy in 1998 named the 100 sexiest female stars of the 20th century, Raquel Welch came in third, after Marilyn Monroe and Jayne Mansfield.
When Playboy in 1998 named the 100 sexiest female stars of the 20th century, Raquel Welch came in third, after Marilyn Monroe and Jayne Mansfield.

results.title: Hari Nef and Parker Posey: Two ‘It’ Girls Whose ‘Humanity Peeks Through’
results.abstract: In a pairing that seems almost predestined, the actresses are sharing a stage in “The Seagull/Woodstock, NY,” a contemporary riff on Chekhov.

results.title: Hugh Hudson, Director of ‘Chariots of Fire,’ Dies at 86
results.abstract: His first film — about two runners, one Christian, one Jewish, who compete at the 1924 Summer Olympics — won four Oscars, including for best picture.

multimedia.caption: The director Hugh Hudson, left, in 1981 with Ben Cross, one of the stars of “Chariots Of Fire.” Mr. Hudson’s first feature film, it was nominated for seven Oscars and won four.
multimedia.copyright: Warner Bros./Archive Photos, via Getty Images

results.title: A Man Hanging From a Clock. Yes, It’s That Silent Film.
results.abstract: “Safety Last!,” the 1923 Harold Lloyd movie best known for the dangerous scene, marks its centennial.

multimedia.caption: Harold Lloyd in the 1923 movie “Safety Last!” A safety net was constructed on a roof about one floor below the action, though the scene was shot to look as though there was a sheer drop to the bustling streets far below.

results.title: Carlos Saura, a Leading and Enduring Spanish Director, Dies at 91
results.abstract: Called “one of the fundamental filmmakers in the history of Spanish cinema,” he began making movies under Franco, often hiding his messages in allegory.

multimedia.caption: Carlos Saura in 2017. He was adept at getting around government censors during the Franco dictatorship.
Carlos Saura in 2017. He was adept at getting around government censors during the Franco dictatorship.

results.title: Sandra Seacat, Much Admired Acting Coach, Dies at 86
results.abstract: She helped Laura Dern, Marlo Thomas, Mickey Rourke and many others overcome fears, find their characters and discover “the joy of acting.”

results.title: Solomon Perel, Jew Who Posed as a Hitler Youth to Survive, Dies at 97
results.abstract: His masquerade — a tale recounted in a memoir and in the film “Europa Europa” — saved his life. But “to this day,” he said, “I have a tangle of two souls in one body.”

multimedia.caption: Solomon Perel in an undated photo. “I’m not a Jew,” he lied to his Wehrmacht captors in 1941. “I’m an ethnic German.”
Solomon Perel in an undated photo. “I’m not a Jew,” he lied to his Wehrmacht captors in 1941. “I’m an ethnic German.”

results.title: How the Oscars and Grammys Thrive on the Lie of Meritocracy
results.abstract: Despite all the markers of excellence, contenders like Danielle Deadwyler, Viola Davis and Beyoncé weren’t recognized for the highest honors. Niche awards don’t suffice.

multimedia.caption: Danielle Deadwyler in “Till.” She had to show public restraint as a grieving mother, while other actresses were lauded for emotional excess.
multimedia.copyright: Lynsey Weatherspoon/Orion Pictures, via Associated Press
